segments.text: well-known as a writer of some of our keen nonfiction, first essay, and recently a book on, of all things, libraries.
Baker, a self-suppressed lover of books and of libraries, paradoxically began writing enduring enmity of many libraries when he wrote about the destruction of car catalogs in the New Yorker in 1994.
His latest passion is for the preservation of original prints, particularly newspapers, a goal he has supported personally by founding the American newspaper repository.
Baker's newest book, Double Full, Librarians and the Assault on Paper, was published in April.
On my near right is Professor Richard Cox, who hails from the University of Pittsburgh School of Information Sciences.
Dr. Cox, a highly respected voice among archivists, has written extensively on professional issues in archives and records management.
He has countered Baker's arguments vigorously.
Originally in First Monday, a peer-reviewed internet journal,
And most recently, in a preliminary review of Baker's books for the Society of American Archivists, entitled Don't Fold Up.
Cox offers a professional archivist's perspective on the complex issues that surround the preservation of the past.
Of course, an event like today could never happen without the hard work.
I would like to thank my fellow Alumni Day Committee members, Linda Watkins, Susan Lieberthal,
and Toby Pearl.
The committee would also like to thank giftless professor Jeanette Bastion and student David Weaver, who suggested this morning the speakers.
In addition, the alumni office and Dean Matarazzo's office have provided much assistance and guidance.
Finally, our thanks to our two speakers, who have graciously agreed to air their disagreements in public here today.
Mr. Baker will begin, followed by Dr. Cox.
After their more formal remarks, the speakers will take questions from the audience.
At that point, listeners in the overflow room are invited to come into this room in order to ask their questions if they'd like.
Dean Matarato has graciously agreed to provide a little Q&A period.
Over to you, gentlemen.
Well, thank you.
Good morning, everybody.
I'm honored to be here at Simmons.
And I'd like first to say a second thank you to David Weaver, who, as a student in Jeannette Bastion's archives class, read the New York article that I've written about the fate of old newspapers and
asked me last year if I needed some help.

And my wife and I had, at that time, 60 pallets of old newspapers, many more tons, mostly bound, bought directly or indirectly from the British Library after I tried, unsuccessfully, to move into the library to leave them.
And we're sitting in a brick textile mill in Rollinsford, New Hampshire.
Please raise your hand if you can hear me.
And they've been packed by the library in more or less random order.

of the titles we bought were the last remaining intact long runs in any library if we had bought them on behalf of a non-profit that i formed they would be cut up and sold piecemeal by a dealer who was in the birthday newspaper and historical headline business so yes we needed help david weaver got a simmons internship approved despite the fact that i am not a professional librarian or a professional archivist
And he broke up on weekends, and he and I began unwrapping pallets and sorting through hundreds of volumes.
We got two shelves up.
He did some inventories, and he gave the whole enterprise a massive forward boost.

Now, with the further help of a few dozen volunteers, the question is mostly sorted and can be used by appointment by people who want to see what these published urban landmarks of 50 or 100 or 120 years ago actually looked like.
So thank you, David.
Thank you, Simmons.
And if some of you want to help out with shelving or indexing over time, we'd be very grateful.
Richard Cox and I are here to talk about original formats in a virtual world.
But it's framed as the great paper debate.
And I feel that so as not to disappoint you all, we should both totter out wearing sumo wrestler diapers and go at it.
Richard zapping me with a handheld laser scanner while I

brandish a 1942 volume of the new york herald tribune there's clearly a feeling in some quarters that by criticizing in detail noble institutions such as the library of congress and famous washington library leaders such as berger clapp and patricia batten that i have wrongly demeaned the entire profession of librarianship i don't think that's true i believe on the contrary
that I'm protecting the integrity of the profession of librarianship from some very powerful people who led it astray.

The people I criticize were those who, in my opinion, used lots of federal money to push libraries into making terribly destructive mistakes, mistakes that we will never be able to recover from fully.
We must learn more about the evolution of these mistakes and the little euphemisms such as preservation and reformatting that shielded them from view so as not to repeat them.

I wrote the book not just because I'm upset by what's happened, which I certainly am, but because librarians who knew much more about the day-to-day realities of libraries than an outsider like me knows told me that they were upset about what's happened.

There are librarians who feel completely powerless in their institutions, who know that what is going on is wrong, but who haven't been able to communicate that wrong to anyone who can expose it or counteract it.
Just last week, I got a letter from some librarians at the Library of Congress.
I'd like to read you some of it.
These librarians write, some of us have had our professional careers abolished for standing up against the mass destruction of the nation's literary heritage.
By writing this letter, we will again be under fire and in danger of losing our jobs.
And top library managers do not tolerate dissent from the party line.
We have been told that the sixth floor
a nickname for library management, is upset by our contact with you.
We protest this siege mentality.
Writers of this letter call the Library of Congress's preservation program misguided.
The problems of storing books and newspapers are resolvable, they say.
The problems of politics and egos are another matter.
As I'm sure all of you here know, there's nothing monolithic about what librarians think

which is why I point out in the preface to my book that great libraries employ, and here I'm quoting, a great many book-respecting people who may not know of or approve of what their superiors or their forebears have done.
We need a national library that's willing to commit to the ordered storage of the things that people have actually published and read.
Whole cities once read the newspapers a hundred years ago.
No other sources of words
and imagery entered so many minds consistently every day.
50 years ago, the Library of Congress had 67,000 bound volumes of late 19th and 20th century newspapers from every big city in the country.
According to a man who did a collection well, these files were immaculate.
They couldn't wait to get rid of them, he told me.
Of this intergenerational bounty, only a few thousand volumes remained to be my profound.
The rest have already gone.
And much of the microfilm that replaced the original papers was bought and filed away sight unseen without even a spot check for quality.

One of the tragedies of newspaper industry is that the biggest and most important papers, the New York Times, the Herald Tribune, the Chicago Tribune, were microfilmed earliest and least well because they were the ones that were likely to sell to other libraries.
And then those libraries sold or dumped their originals.
Why do you need to keep the originals?

they're beautiful and interesting and old of course because the paper that they are made of is the very paper that went through the four and six color whole printing presses at the time and thus they are the best and thus they are best able to convey the complete testimony of the past and just as important because they serve as a source for
The New York Times Company and Bell and Howell have announced that they will be selling libraries a digital facsimile of the Times going back to 1851.
That's great.
But where do they turn to make their digital facsimiles?
The Times doesn't have a file of its own paper.
And the New York Public Library's run has large gaps, including a 10-year gap from 1915 to 1925.
So digitizers are turning to Bell and Howell's microfilm of the Times.
The electronic version will come not from the original, but from black and white film, and much of the richness of the line art and the road reviewer photography sections will be lost.

And no matter how good Bell & Howell's de-spackling software, that's what they call it, is, and no matter how high their scanning resolution is, they will once again be selling libraries, many of whom once owned the Times in the original, something that looks like mediocre microfilm.
The searchable text that comes from the scanned file is going to be a mess at times because the OCR software isn't going to have enough information to chew on.
My wish that libraries do a better job in keeping what people actually read and have read is independent of what may happen with electronic publishing.
Maybe in two years or two months, most people will be reading the New York Times and books exclusively as phosphors on the screen.
If so, keep screen images of the phosphors.
At the moment, though, most people read the Times as sheets of Raleigh paper covered with pictures and advertisements.
And yet no library right now is keeping the New York Times in paper, not one as far as I know.
Libraries subscribe to the Times and the microfilm of the Times, and then they talk about the paper after a brief holding period.
I'm not alone in being surprised and just paid attention.
Most people I've talked to are.
And like saying,
that libraries should be saving every single copy of every edition of every single paper in the country?
Of course not.
I'm saying that right now we're saving no current copies, zero, and clearly we can do better than this.
And I'm saying that once upon a time, libraries owned, just by happenstance, different editions of the same daily papers, because they've been sent different editions, which they found,
in their wisdom, and these textual differences, these differing headlines and pictures and articles were lost when they substituted the unvarying microfilm copy for what they had.
And I'm saying that the US newspaper program is still today paying libraries to film old originals and then allowing them to throw the papers out to free up space.
Does that mean that I insist that libraries must save everything?
At the turn of the last century,
Joseph Pulitzer published half a million or a million copies of the New York world every day.
Almost all of these copies are gone.
They're cut up, burned, destroyed, because that's the way life is.
Most of what we publish is lost.
But I do believe we need to keep a few original copies of what is that draw most influential paper in our history, just a few.
Not everything, but one 500,000
of everything.

A culture that is able to save locomotives and space capsules and wallpaper collections and gardens full of enormous rusting pieces of sculpture and the correspondence of untold numbers of minor historical figures and rare strains of disease germs can, I think, find a way to hold onto something as centrally important as this.
Of course, every library and archive and historical society worries about shelf space.
Librarians tussle over shelf space within their own institutions.
But compared with making digital copies or microfilm copies, space is cheap.

It would cost my little nonprofit tens of millions of dollars to create digital images of the millions of pages of newspapers it owns in color at a resolution that would allow researchers to read them comfortably.
On the other hand, it costs us $26,000 a year to rent the space to keep them safe.
As a country, we've really got to do a better job of weighing these relative costs.
Drive from Boston to New York and look at the warehouses.
There are hundreds of them.
Some of them have 50 truck bays.
What are they holding?
They're holding cheese products for truck parts or Happy Meal toys, for Pentium computers that will be scrapped in five years.
Some of them are police.

a few big room clean warehouses withhold everything that our national library has been sent free by publishers and has rejected every year our national library says that they don't have enough space and they are unwilling to leave space even though they're willing to budget 94 million dollars for digital questions just a little more about space last month i gave a talk at the ribbon cutting ceremony at the new storage facility from duke university library
It's a building like the Harvard Depository, where things are stored in random order, reached by a state-of-the-art cherry picker.
The building costs $7.5 million to build, and it will hold 2.5 million books.
So a brand-new, ultra-cool book building costs only $3 a book to build.
A tiny number of the books that are going into that building have been digitally scanned.
And here's the salient comparison.
To store a 19th-century book in this warehouse, it costs $3 a book.
plus an estimated 17 cents a book in maintenance and static.
To scan a 19th century book, it costs at least $100 a book.
If you want to scan it in color at high resolution, costs leap up from there.
And the physical book doesn't need periodic refreshing on new media.
It doesn't need platform migration.
It doesn't even need an electrical outlet.
Not that it's a bad thing to take digital pictures of books, as long as the picture taken doesn't require that the book be cut out of its binding and guillotined.
The electric versions can be extraordinarily useful.
I prefer that book collections were stored in traditional call number order, browsably, which costs a little more, say $10 a book.
But the point is that off-site storage, even traditional call number storage, is the cheapest thing it can possibly do
to maintain access to a collection.

And any scanning or microfilming that big research libraries embark on in the name of remote access should be, from now on, be done with the expectation that the original book go back on the shelf when the copying is done.
There's a lot of money for digitization right now.
If we set things up so that we tied 10% into a paper conservancy fund as we digitized to provide the safekeeping of the original afterward, we'd be just fine.
In fact, at the beginning of a scanned or OCR or microfilms document, it might be nice to read, no originals were harmed.
Research library collections grow.
Your children's feet grow, and you buy them new shoes.
The bigger feet do not represent a growth problem, but a developmental fact, something to be proud of.
For the past half century or more, though, growth has been an embarrassment to some Washington visionaries.
They were swept by a kind of Cold War fervor of informational reform, and they wanted all growth to stop.
Libraries would reach a certain fixed size, a few million volumes, and then the weeding parties would gather.

and the microcopying would crunch down the excess, and when the microfilm schools themselves took up too much room, and they could microcopy the microcopies at ultra-high resolution, and crunch things down more, and the stacks would function like a vast trash compactor, squeezing the words.
Because words were squeezable, weren't they?
They were disembodied astral presences that had nothing to do with the ink that formed them, or the paper that they were printed on, or the findings that held paper together.
They could be reformatted, preserved by being destroyed, because they were immaterial.
The books would still exist.
They would just not exist.
They would be there, but they wouldn't be there.
You could hold your head high and say you had the finest US newspaper collection in the world, but in fact, you got rid of 90% of it and replaced it with microphones.
What was the source of this thinking?
There was one especially influential person, some of you may have heard about, most of you may have heard about.
His name was Fremont Ryder.
head librarian at Weston.
Ryder's first book published in 1909 was about the amazing discoveries of spirit wrappings and table turnings and levitation.
He felt these things deserve serious study, and that the tables did, in fact, turn.
He wrote Pulp Fiction.
He was the managing editor of the Library Journal.
And when he went bankrupt in 1929, after a manic episode in which he spent a small fortune founding a supper club on Long Island,
He wrote an indignant pamphlet in which he said that people were fed up with being indebted to banks, and they wanted a new deal.
He sent the pamphlet to Franklin D. Roosevelt, and Roosevelt shot him back a letter with a handwritten note saying, you're right, keep it up.
And a few months later, Roosevelt, in his nomination speech, pledged himself to a new deal for the American people.
So Fremont Reiter was an influential person, and his new deal for librarians was this.
Make or buy micro copies of your book collection, sell off the book collection to dealers at scrap prices, and you will make, in his words, an actual cash profit on the substitution.
You'll enrich your library by getting rid of its books.

Lider got the Librarian of Congress, and the Deputy Librarian of Congress, and the Head Librarian at Michigan, and the Head Librarian at Harvard, and other big time leaders all over the library world to blurb his book and serve on his microcard committee.
It's a mathematical fact that book collections double every 16 years, Ryder said.
Turns out he was wrong about that.
And if we didn't start buying Fremont Ryder's microcard reading machines and selling off the collections, the stacks were going to overrun the entire square footage of New Jersey.
Building a storage warehouse was, according to Ryder, a confession of past failure.
It was unmanly.

This way of thinking continues in some libraries, and it was very powerful in the 1980s, when the Library of Congress had high votes for its optical disk pilot project, which could, according to the deputy librarian, squeeze down the library's three buildings to one.
But the optical disk pilot program didn't work out.
Nobody uses both big platters anymore.
And over the past decade or so, some enlightened library administrators have begun to accept the fact that the easiest way to keep a research collection

is to keep the research collection there's no shame in growth it's not a confession of failure putting up shelves sufficient to hold what's there is the crucially important primary task that research fibers must fulfill they must do this because no other institutions public or private can be dependent on to keep these things the obscure things the cumbersome things but even though they're used only once in 10 years
or 30 years, or 50 years, are valuable because they are what people published and said.
To a literature, the fact that something is little used is a positive attribute.

If a photo editor for a documentary on, say, Ellis Island pages through the Road of Revere section of a newspaper or a forgotten autobiography and finds a picture that has never been reproduced before, she is overjoyed because the picture is interesting and because it's unused.
We till around in great collections looking for things that have lain unnoticed.
The urge to search through obscurity is basic scholarship.
If the research libraries don't keep it, don't keep copies of the stuff that we as a culture publish, nobody else is going to do it.
It just won't happen.
We can't depend on businesses to save our past.
We just care about the present and they go out of business.
We understand why fragile old flags and old presidential letters are valuable as things.
We don't believe that taking a snapshot of Plymouth Rock amounts to a reformatting of Plymouth Rock.
And after some long and painful decades of urban renewal, we're doing better with old mills and train stations.
There are very nice postcards of Whistler's Woman in White in museum gift shops, but Whistler's Woman in White is still on the wall.
If libraries ask for storage money with the same intensity, they ask for digitizing or microfilming money.
If they budget it right into the grant proposals for digitization, the public will understand and oblige.
We really want you to keep this stuff.
Now, I want to talk for a last moment about conspiracies and personal negative.
In a well-written place,
previously mentioned, called Don't Fold Up.
Responding to Nicholson Baker's double fold, Richard Cox says several times that I present conspiracy theories in my book.
I just don't.
I do point out in the book that some of the great library leaders and theorists of the 50s and 60s worked for the CIA in the department of defense.
I never use the word conspiracy.

joseph becker a senior cia informationalist designed the library of the future exhibits at the seattle and the new york world fair herman fustler head of the university of chicago library had been the chief librarian of the manhattan project and he was a consultant to the economic energy commission bernard class the deputy librarian of congress and later the founder of the multi-influential library group the council on library resources
was a CIA liaison and consultant for decades with top secret clearance as were several of the other board members of the council on library resources.
Now when I first stumbled on this, and I was just trying to find out a little more about Werner Clappen,
since he was the most influential librarian at the time, I found it all quite fascinating.

And I think that there's a lot more work to be done by library historians in teasing out the way that the intelligence community has in certain areas hired librarians to help them with their enormous indexing and filing and classifying problems.
Obviously, the informational needs of the CIA and the DOD, swift but eyes only movement, instant retreatability, ease of record destruction,
are different from the informational needs of someone slowly accumulating research in a particular immigrant neighborhood in Boston in 1906.
And for a long time, I believe, intelligence requirements had an undue influence on decision-making at some libraries.
None of this amounts to a conspiracy, however.
Herman Klatt and Herman Fosterowitz were sincere information scientists of a certain stripe who strongly believed that you could reform libraries

and win the cold war finally about my personal conductive mostly i simply quote what people say to me or what they've written when i disagree with what they say i say so the subtitle of my book libraries and the assault on paper comes from a passage written by patricia batten in 1983 when she says that her university depended on
outside funding, this is a quote, and cooperative projects for an active assault on our large collection of brittle materials.
I do criticize acts, terrible acts, of needless destruction.

We were told that the large-scale federal brittle books program began at the National Endowment for the Humanities in the late 1980s, supplant microfilm, three million books over 20 years, pushed by Patricia Batten and others,
was a way of saving the human record.

But if you read the planning document on which the Brittle Books program was built, we learned that built into the plan was the idea that if one library microfilmed a book, then five libraries could discard their copies of the book, which would amount to a space savings of hundreds of millions of dollars.
The Brittle Books program was sold as a kind of emergency book rescue, but it was in fact predicated on book destruction.
It's time the public and librarians knew of this inversion of impact.
Libraries win or lose the public's trust based on their actions.
And the only way we can evaluate the trustworthiness of their actions is if we know what the actions are.
And yet it is today extremely difficult to find out what libraries like the Library of Congress choose to discard.
And so to close, I'd like to recommend that all research libraries that receive public money
be required to post lists of proposed discards on their websites.
There's a giant hole in the 20th century as a result of the casualties of micro-filming projects, but we have a chance to do it right this time around.
Offer the boom of networked pages without destroying the riches of local collections.
Thank you.
Does the slide show set up?
The slide projector?
Oh great.
I don't have a thing.
So when I want to switch the slide, do I just say next?
I want to show you just some slides of the

because um i think if i just sit here and say a note paper they're beautiful and they're precious and they shouldn't have been thrown out that's fine but if if i show you some pictures of what i'm talking about you'll be able to judge for yourself whether these things have informational value in their illustrations say that the microphone doesn't fully capture
This is what the New York world looks like in the era of rag paper before Joseph Pulitzer bought it.
It's only eight pages long because rag paper was extremely expensive.
There were periodic rag shortages.

and they had to jam everything onto these eight pages so they used a very tiny type but they didn't really have briefing on them Pulitzer and Hearst came to New York City and they transformed the way people read the news here's the same newspaper in 1898 after the installation of I think their second huge printing press
The most marvelous mechanical production of the age is what they call this printing press.
And they have an illustration here of the color pages going through it, being cut and folded, and then followed by eight pages of color fashion illustrations.
So this was really the key to the success of these pictures, was that they were offering a readership color that they hadn't seen before.
You could get a whole list in every Sunday for very, very cheap.
Pulitzer and Hearst were competing, and this is an illustration that's also in the book, to show the finest battle illustrations in 1898.
So here on its side, to take advantage of the full size of the page, is an illustration with a raking searchlight.

And then on the right, you can see the trajectory of a shell that leaves the battleship on the left, and it rises up over a column of type in the middle, and then lands on the shore on the right-hand side.
So they're really thinking about the way the paper looked as a graphic thing.
This muck wrecking, there's lots of muck wrecking in these turn-of-the-century papers obviously.
This is the problem sweatshops, the man sewing on the left, the sweatshop owner in the middle, selling to the rich woman on the right.
She's one of the 400.
And then this is the same thing on microfilm.
This is the New York Public Library's film, which is what everybody's film is, made in 1951.
And one of the problems is that you have to kind of reassemble it out of 8 12 by 11 printouts.
And it's just not the same.
Here is a cartoon from 1898.
The cartoon pages are incredible.
The Persecution Mania, kind of pre-Freudian thing, with the Red Devil inside them on the left.
Divorced in one Dakota day, it says, and there's a man on the left, a woman on the right, and I've seen the vignettes of their divorce, their Dakota divorce going through.
These newspapers, like the world, have never been indexed.
One of the problems is that you can't find what's in here because
There's no way to find it.
So one of the things I'm hoping to do is to do a kind of modest pilot project indexing the magazine sections of some of the world.
Another cartoon.
This is the labor-saving dodges for the hot weather and the man up in the upper left is diving into an automatic undressing machine.
This is all pre-Ruth Goldberg but very Ruth Goldbergian.
On the left, lower left, is a
robotic lover who takes care of that while the man kind of lounges on the settee.
This is the same thing on microfilm.
You still see the robotic lover, you still see this undressing machine, but it just doesn't kind of leap out at you.
Microfilm is a high contrast medium, which means it wants to be either black or white, which in the case of a color illustration isn't ideal.
This just shows one of the things that the British Library was most scrupulous about.
They had to stamp every volume discarded by the British Library or BL canceled.

First they were stamping everything in black and some of the stamping was actually obscuring the text so I asked if they could at least use a different color so they resorted to green but then they stamped in this case right in the guy's head.
Boom.
And then another bear.
This is probably the last
remaining range of this without a copy of that illustration certainly many libraries.
From 1900 to 1930 there isn't any other library as far as I know but half of the New York world in the original.
The American Antiquarian Society has a run of the world through 1900s so fortunately between the American newspaper repositories run and the American Antiquarian Society run there is now
one complete run of Joseph Pulitzer's masterpiece.
This is the magazine section, which is a huge full-size print on the regular newsprint stock.
Every week there was some illustration.
This is the hazards of a newly electrified New York City.
All these pictures are from the first decade of the 20th century.
Lots of maps of New York underground always.
bridges, and they were just seizing with pride in this newly powerful city, and the newspapers stood for all that.
New York churches turned into dives, a boxing match in a church on the lower half.
New York's first airship station, I think probably its last.
They had to have airships.
There was just an obsession with airships, really.
An airship every Sunday.
The Gret airship.
And this is how the eclipse works.
Kind of a nice one from, I think, 1905 or something.
And how the Chinese treatment of the eclipse on the lower right.
And then the eclipse on microfilm.
There is no eclipse on microfilm.
There.
This is a digital photograph, by the way, I can say proudly.
Who gets your money?
And it's John D. Rockefeller, Morgan, and Ryan all sharpening their axes as the whole guy turns the wheel.
And then in the lower left corner, around the perimeter, there are all the products, like shoes and candles and railroads and everything.
Then Morgan, Rockefeller, and Ryan all conjointly control a wonderful
conspiracy theory there.
How far can New York climb into the sky?

And this is a composite illustration of New York's finest buildings, including the Pulitzer Building, which is second from the right, which was torn down in 1954, about the time that the New York Public Library was microfilming.
Yes, I know.
The Sunday Magazine shows the heroic rescue of our great firemen.
showing off the printing press.
And then there were lots of fashion pages.
This is a hat.
They had to have a hat in every issue as well.
And then on the right, Gibson Girl inserts, which are carefully bound in by the British Library.
And generally don't appear on the microfilm because they're easily stolen.
There are many things that don't appear on the microfilm.
Whole new sections don't.
Because each microfilm
set was unique in a way.
They all were missing things and they all had slightly different editions and so each one of them is sort of like a magical falter or something that has the variations that are interesting.
Inside these magazine sections are incredible things.
The dumbbell might be in the corset on the right.
During the New York world, in the first third of the 20th century, the world was really neat literary New York paper, and it published Robert Bensley and E.B.
White and Dorothy Parker's poem, Men Don't Make Passes at Girls Who Wear Glass, the first published in the world.
It was the New Yorker magazine before the New Yorker magazine existed, and yet there is really no run of this thing around, except this one, as far as I know.
He was a nice illustration of a liar.
Henry, on the lower left, was a staff writer and had a short story almost every week in the world.
On the upper left is Norbert Wiener, before Norbert Wiener became a famous cyberneticist and war scientist who protected nuclear weapons.
And here on the right is the adventures of a man who dressed up as an Italian tambourine girl and wrote about it.
On the left is the hazards of being a diver in the docks of New York City.
On the right here is a man named Leonard who was born without a nose and he wanted a nose very much and so two doctors said that they would give him a nose by sewing his finger to his face.
and allowing them to have it heal there, then they would agitate the finger.

Well, Mr. Leonard was okay with this for a while, and then he began to be driven crazy by this finger in his face all night and all night, and so he tore it away, and then he decided he would do it again.
So they sewed it back, and then he tore it away again, and sewed it back, and finally he
according to the reporter, left the hospital with the foundations of a new nose firmly attached to his face.
Sometimes the things that experts think are the right thing to do are not the right thing to do.
Lots of plans for the beauties of New York had to come.
and of beauties of New York that exist.
Of course, there are airships on top.
I'm sorry, I'm slow with these.
They hired German, French Italian illustrators in 1911 to come to New York and illustrate the strangeness of the city.
So here's some grotesque that a German illustrator noticed on a rooftop.
And here in 1927, a smaller magazine section, women raised chariots in the hippodrome, latest excavations.

There were many other runs, very rare and beautiful runs of immigrant newspapers, all published in the United States, that were part of this discarding program at the British Library, which had the finest more newspaper collection anywhere.
Irish World from the turn of the century.
All the guts were heard.
The New York Tribune also, just to show you that there are other papers in this thing, and Record Act, Microfilm of the Tribune, the Pale Blue is no longer there.
And the Road of Revere sections, which are pervasive in all the great newspapers really through the 40s.
I printed in much higher resolution on thicker stock.
And they're one of the real losses when you go to microfilm, because they just lose.
You see the sprocket markings, but you don't see the half pounds.
The New York Forward is another beautiful run.
Here's one from 1941.
It also has wrote a review section.
And it says, this is the world that the Jewish children of today have inherited.
The pictures of refugees.
